Thoughts Anish Shah 2020-05-25 Chapter 1 Prerequisites This is not an organize series of chapters yet. This is likely a living book that will change over time. There will be likely several sections technical: involving Rmarkdown, Github, Vim, MATLAB physiology: medically related topics ecg: concepts taken from signal processing efforts, including morphology and heart rate variability analyses This is a sample book written in Markdown. You can use anything that Pandocâ€™s Markdown supports, e.g., a math equation \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\). The bookdown package can be installed from CRAN or Github: install.packages("bookdown") # or the development version # devtools::install_github("rstudio/bookdown") Remember each Rmd file contains one and only one chapter, and a chapter is defined by the first-level heading #. 1.1 This project is built with several libraries from CRAN bookdown pkgdown

Chapter 2 Introduction 2.1 Overview This is a collection of posts built using R, serving as documentation for my current clinical and research workflow. You can label chapter and section titles using {#label} after them, e.g., we can reference Chapter 2. If you do not manually label them, there will be automatic labels anyway, e.g., Chapter 3. Figures and tables with captions will be placed in figure and table environments, respectively. par(mar = c(4, 4, .1, .1)) plot(pressure, type = 'b', pch = 19) Figure 2.1: Here is a nice figure! Reference a figure by its code chunk label with the fig: prefix, e.g., see Figure 2.1. Similarly, you can reference tables generated from knitr::kable(), e.g., see Table 2.1. knitr::kable( head(iris, 20), caption = 'Here is a nice table!', booktabs = TRUE ) Table 2.1: Here is a nice table! For example, we are using the bookdown package (Xie 2020) in this sample book, which was built on top of R Markdown and knitr (Xie 2015). References
Chapter 3 Technical Tools 3.1 R 3.2 Github 3.3 Terminal

Chapter 3 Technical Tools When working between Windows, Linux, and macOS systems, having a similar experience is important to maintain workflows. Key features that make the workflow similar are: linux kernel (WSL-2) terminal (iTerm2, wsltty) package manager (homebrew) shell (zsh, bash) tiling system (tmux) email (neomutt) version control (github) programming (R and RStudio) 3.1 R Built using R. Currently using R.version. 3.2 Github Maintained and version controlled using git. 3.3 Terminal Tmux - a screen multiplexer with a powerline bar to make a pleasant experience across systems.

Chapter 4 Vectorcardiography The movement of electricity around the heart is at times more revealing then a specific diagnosis. Clinically, relevant vector/morphology based features include: vector gradient primary versus secondary T-wave abnormalities atrial abnormalities identify foci of ectopy 4.1 Computational Approach Global electrical heterogeneity.
